tags.name: Wed 4-5 Lecture: Data representation: integer, pointer, float

posts.question: In the sum.c exercise in this lecture there is the following prototype at the top of the file: int sumOf(int *, int); This doesn't actually make any mention of the variable names given as input to the function. Is this legal in prototypes in C?
answers: Yes: prototypes exist only to give the compiler an idea of the existence of a function, and the types it takes in and returns. Of course, you need to provide variable names when implementing a function.
